Water supply and distribution in larger communities
items.abstract: <jats:p>Water utilities are perhaps the hardest hit of all utilities faced with inflation and customer resistance to rate and tax increases, because their ratios of capital investment to revenue are the highest of the basic utilities. This article describes how the Chicago water system is dealing with these problems.</jats:p>

Locating Centers on a Tree with Discontinuous Supply and Demand Regions
items.abstract: <jats:p> Consider a tree T = (N, E) with “supply” and “demand” regions Σ and Δ, each composed of a finite number of disjoint, closed and connected subregions of T, some of which may possibly consist of just one point. Given an integer p, we seek a collection of p “centers” x<jats:sub>1</jats:sub>, …, x<jats:sub>p</jats:sub> ∈ Σ, which minimize the expression max<jats:sub>y∈δ</jats:sub> min<jats:sub>i=1,…,p</jats:sub>d(y, x<jats:sub>i</jats:sub>). We present a polynomial algorithm for this problem. Its running time is bounded by O(n log<jats:sup>2</jats:sup>n) if either Δ or Σ is discrete, and by O(n min|p log<jats:sup>2</jats:sup>n,n log p|) if both sets contain at least one full edge. </jats:p>

Effect of augmentation of nerve supply upon limb regeneration in the chick embryo
items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Limb regeneration was induced in 4‐day chick embryos by implanting stage 15 neural tube into the amputated stump of the limb. In control animals, amputation alone or amputation with implant of either notochord or somites resulted in development of proximal wing segments only. In experimental animals, more than one‐fourth of the animals containing viable neural tube implants developed proximal, middle, and distal limb segments. These regenerated limb segments contained muscle groups, cartilage models, and nervous structures that approximated the normal situations. Since some new parts regenerated in more than one‐fourth of the cases, it may be concluded that augmentation of nerve supply is an effective method of inducing regeneration in limbs of chick embryos. Volume measurements of the neural tube implant indicate that a “critical mass” of nerve tissue may be necessary for regeneration to occur.</jats:p>

Private Investment in Forest Management and the Long‐Term Supply of Timber
items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Timber supply behavior of private forest owners is a major uncertainty in long‐term forest product market projections. A model of private supply is developed that explains both harvest and forest management investment decisions. Comparison of two fifty‐year projections, one assuming constant management intensity and a second using the harvest‐investment model, indicates that projected levels of investment would (<jats:italic>a</jats:italic>) have little impact on markets prior to the year 2000, (<jats:italic>b</jats:italic>) stabilize real wood product prices after 2000, (<jats:italic>c</jats:italic>) eliminate softwood lumber imports by 2030, and (<jats:italic>d</jats:italic>) expand the dominant role of southern forest regions in wood product markets.</jats:p>
